hardware the floppy disk driver in the
Linux kernel has been marked as orphaned
which means that no developer can work
on it any more this usually leads to
that specific driver being deprecated or
removed down the line this only concerns
the old floppy disk driver hardware the
treats floppy through USB uses a
different newer driver that is still
supported still it means that in a few
months or years older floppy hardware
won't be supported by the Linux kernel
anymore

citing their will to provide as many

additionally Manjaro rolled another

strange to me 31st of July blender 2.8
was released bringing a huge number of
improvements to an already stellar piece
of software among the big changes the
user interface has been completely
redesigned with new icons and a darker
theme it also uses the all-new Eevee
real-time renderer which should have way
better performance and the ability to
quickly switch between different UIs for
various tasks such as 3d modeling video
editing visual effects and other stuff
blender can do if your blender user make
sure you grab that new release proton
4.11 was released based on wine 4.11
this brings a ton of enhancements on top
of the proton specific changes that have
been upstream to wine this new proton
version brings an updated DX v KF audio
but also support for D 9vk directly from
valve although it's not enabled by
default all of the modules are also
built as Windows PE files and not Linux
libraries which should help anti-cheat
software work better with proton and
Steam play work is also underway to
replace the e sync patches with a new
solution called F sync which should
reduce overhead and resource consumption
in multi-threaded games it's a huge
release and should be offered by default
as the new proton version in steam Linux
Mint 19.2 was released bringing a lot of
improvements over the previous iteration
most notably the older kernel versions
now show if they are outdated or not an
installation and removal of kernels can
be cute means report the system info
tool has a better layout and displays
more legible information with a new page
showing some system info for quick copy
pasting in bug reports
cinnamons memory usage has been greatly
reduced and the window manager has
reduced input lag as well you can also
enable or disable vsync without
restarting the desktop environment the
main menu no differentiates between
duplicate apps such as with flat pack
score of our behavior can now be
configured in the settings files can be
pinned to a specific folder in the file
manager and a lot of smaller
improvements have been added as well to
the default apps and theme existing
users should upgrade and users not
familiar with mint might want to give it
a try and that's it for this Linux and
open-source news recap for the month of
July
